Merged pull request "Move packaging classes to own files" (#322) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: Many of the files have 5+ classes in them (and some have many more). This makes it very difficult to find classes and makes for very long, unmaintainable files. This is part of #315 and starts with bringing all the classes within the `DocumentFormat.OpenXml.Packaging` namespace into the folder, with each class being in their own file.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Separate sources1.cs to own files" (#323) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: This is a part of #315 and moves classes from sources1.cs to their own files. This file had around multiple namespaces and classes which are now located in folders based on their namespace and files based on their type name.

Closed issue "FieldCode is fragmented" (#195) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
When getting fieldcodes using

`document.MainDocumentPart.RootElement.Descendants(Of FieldCode)()`

FieldCode  is fragmented  when Word put the instruction text in multiple  <w:instrText>. 

the xml looks like these
<w:r>
		<w:rPr>
			<w:b />
		</w:rPr>
		<w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin" />
	</w:r>
	<w:r>
		<w:rPr>
			<w:b />
		</w:rPr>
		<w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> MERGEFIELD CHIL</w:instrText>
	</w:r>
	<w:r w:rsidRPr="00611B99">
		<w:rPr>
			<w:b />
			<w:szCs w:val="24" />
		</w:rPr>
		<w:instrText>D2__Person_1_First_Name</w:instrText>
	</w:r>
	<w:r>
		<w:rPr>
			<w:b />
		</w:rPr>
		<w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate" />
	</w:r>
	<w:r>
		<w:rPr>
			<w:b />
		</w:rPr>
		<w:fldChar w:fldCharType="end" />
	</w:r>
 
I am getting two separate fieldcode

- MERGEFIELD CHIL
- D2_Person_1_First_Name


Instead of just one MERGEFIELD CHILD2_Person_1_First_Name

![fieldcodes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12826656/24689289/d705714c-1a08-11e7-98ee-4efce15ff58b.png)

Opened pull request "Document builder enhancements" (#194) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Merged pull request "Merge styles with same name in DocumentBuilder" (#183) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
Solves #181.

Currently implemented with a compile-time feature flag, but this could easily be changed to an optional parameter passed to DocumentBuilder at run-time.

It is likely possible to clean up the section that maps style IDs in references and numberings so that it doesn't have to go through as many elements.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "imported word document not supporting for Listitems" (#193) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
We have use OpenXML power tool 4.5.3.2 in our MVC project for importing word document.  after importing we are allowing user to edit it. But as list-items in Document are  imported with special CSS classes and not as UL LI ,so after hitting enter key  at the end of any bullet list item, next bullet list item wont created automatically. 
Please guide us on, how we can import word document with list-items, so that next list-item will automatically created after hitting enter key in Edit mode.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MarkupSimplifier.SimplifyMarkup w:hint issue" (#192) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
OpenXML power tools 4.5.3.2 from Nuget.

When I edit my docx in a RUN with <w:hint="east asia">.

It will add new RUNs with or without <w:hint>.

Then the SimplifyMarkup method can not merge this new RUNs.

Any help?

My tricky work round is Add the same <w:int> to each adjacent runs.

But i don't know if some bad things will happen.

I have read the document about hint:

> hint (Font Content Type) | Specifies the  font type which shall be used to format any ambiguous characters in the current  run.   There are  certain characters which are not explicitly stored in the document, and can be  mapped into multiple categories of the four mentioned above. This attribute  shall be used to arbitrate that conflict, and determine how ambiguities in this  run shall be handled. [Note: This is  primarily used to handle the formatting on the paragraph mark glyph, and other  characters that are not stored as text in the WordprocessingML document. end note]   If this  attribute is omitted, then this ambiguity can be resolved by any means  available.   [Example: Consider the run representing the  paragraph mark glyph, which is not stored as a physical character. Since this  could therefore be formatted with any of the fonts specified for the run, this  ambiguity is resolved using the following WordprocessingML:   <w:pPr><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:hint="eastAsia"  /></w:rPr></w:pPr>   The hint attribute specifies that the run must use the eastAsia font  (theme or not, whichever is in use for East Asian text) as defined for this  range. end example]   The possible  values for this attribute are defined by the ST_Hint  simple type (17.18.41).
